qas.question: How many wars occured between 1500s and 1953?
For bout how many years was an average of one great power fighting another each year?
What country had the most conflicts from 1500s through mid 20th century?
What span was the Pax Britannica?

plausible_answers.text: nineteen such instances against; Russia (8), France (5), Germany/Prussia (5) and Italy (1).

qas.question: Between 1815 and 1914, how many acts of diplomacy were there and with what countries?
How many wars occurred pre-1960, that averaged about 5 years?
Between 1815-1914 what country had the most defining characteristics of diplomacy?
In the 16th century, how many great powers were fighting each other in every year?
During what time frame was diplomacy frequent among the great powers?

context: Referring to great power relations pre-1960, Joshua Baron highlights that starting from around the 16th century and the rise of several European great powers, military conflicts and confrontations was the defining characteristic of diplomacy and relations between such powers. "Between 1500 and 1953, there were <a0_0><b5_0>64<b5_0/><a0_0/> wars in which at least one great power was opposed to another, and they averaged little more than five years in length. In approximately a <a1_0>450<a1_0/>-year time frame, on average <b7_0>at least two great powers<b7_0/> were fighting one another in each and every year." Even during the period of Pax Britannica (or "the British Peace") <a3_0><b8_0>between 1815 and 1914<b8_0/><a3_0/>, war and military confrontations among the great powers was still a frequent occurrence. In fact, Joshua Baron points out that, in terms of militarized conflicts or confrontations, <b6_0>the <a2_0>UK<b6_0/><a2_0/> led the way in this period with <b4_0>nineteen such instances against; Russia (8), France (5), Germany/Prussia (5) and Italy (1).
